articles.headline: Medical Treatment, Out of Reach
articles.snippet: Medical device executives say regulation by the Food and Drug Administration has hurt the industry domestically.
articles.abstract: Medical device executives say regulation by the Food and Drug Administration has hurt the industry domestically.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last year, Biosensors International, a medical device company, shut down its operation in Southern California, which had once housed 90 people, including the company’s top executives and researchers.

articles.headline: Psyched to Buy, in Groups
articles.snippet: Internet-organized group buying has been tried before by the likes of Mercata and MobShop, but Groupon seems to have created the right formula.
articles.abstract: Internet-organized group buying has been tried before by the likes of Mercata and MobShop, but Groupon seems to have created the right formula.
articles.lead_paragraph: You might think that this column is about Groupon.com, the white-hot Web site whose coupons save you 50 to 90 percent at local businesses. But it’s not. It’s about psychology.

articles.headline: The Hands-On Investor
articles.snippet: Brokerage firms and advisers are asking people to share responsibility for managing their wealth by engaging in the process.
articles.abstract: Brokerage firms and advisers are asking people to share responsibility for managing their wealth by engaging in the process.
articles.lead_paragraph: JEANNIE KRIEGER is not your average widowed grandmother.

articles.headline: Certainty on Tax, but Just for Two Years
articles.snippet: The compromise tax law that was enacted in December clarified the tax outlook for the immediate future, but that clarity will last for only two years.
articles.abstract: The compromise tax law that was enacted in December clarified the tax outlook for the immediate future, but that clarity will last for only two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Robert Hassler of Larchmont, N.Y., went to see a lawyer last fall about devising an estate plan, he received two pieces of unexpected advice: wait until Congress enacted changes in tax law, which it did in December, and remain flexible in your planning, so that whatever you do will withstand further changes from Congress.

articles.headline: Counting by Race Can Throw Off Some Numbers
articles.snippet: Lack of uniformity in how Americans are counted by race and ethnicity make analysis difficult.
articles.abstract: Lack of uniformity in how Americans are counted by race and ethnicity make analysis difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal Department of Education would categorize Michelle López-Mullins — a university student who is of Peruvian, Chinese, Irish, Shawnee and Cherokee descent — as “Hispanic.” But the National Center for Health Statistics, the government agency that tracks data on births and deaths, would pronounce her “Asian” and "Hispanic." And what does Ms. López-Mullins’s birth certificate from the State of Maryland say? It doesn’t mention her race.

articles.headline: New Questions Raised in Mortgage Financing
articles.snippet: A suit by a mortgage insurer says that Bear Stearns pocketed money from bad loans instead of putting it toward mortgage bonds.
articles.abstract: A suit by a mortgage insurer says that Bear Stearns pocketed money from bad loans instead of putting it toward mortgage bonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banks have been fighting with disgruntled bond investors and insurers for months, arguing that they do not need to buy back soured mortgages they placed inside securities before the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Playing Catch-Up, Nokia and H.P. Try to Innovate
articles.snippet: The companies in some ways have fallen behind rivals like Apple and Google, and analysts say closing the gap will be difficult.
articles.abstract: The companies in some ways have fallen behind rivals like Apple and Google, and analysts say closing the gap will be difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: In technology markets, playing catch-up is a bruising, costly and often futile game, even for corporate giants.

articles.headline: House Republicans Battle Turmoil in Their Ranks
articles.snippet: Under pressure to make deeper spending cuts and blindsided by floor defeats, Republican leaders are learning the limits of their power over their majority.
articles.abstract: Under pressure to make deeper spending cuts and blindsided by floor defeats, Republican leaders are learning the limits of their power over their majority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under pressure to make deeper spending cuts and blindsided by embarrassing floor defeats, House Republican leaders are quickly discovering the limits of control over their ideologically driven and independent-minded new majority.

articles.headline: Wired and Shrewd, Young Egyptians Guide Revolt
articles.snippet: Some of the young professional leaders of the protest movement have stepped forward to describe their role.
articles.abstract: Some of the young professional leaders of the protest movement have stepped forward to describe their role.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  They were born roughly around the time that President Hosni Mubarak first came to power, most earned degrees from their country’s top universities and all have spent their adult lives bridling at the restrictions of the Egyptian police state  some undergoing repeated arrests and torture for the cause.

articles.headline: Mubarak Refuses to Step Down, Stoking Revolt’s Fury and Resolve
articles.snippet: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt told the Egyptian people Thursday that he would delegate more authority to his vice president, Omar Suleiman, but that he would not resign his post.
articles.abstract: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt told the Egyptian people Thursday that he would delegate more authority to his vice president, Omar Suleiman, but that he would not resign his post.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  President Hosni Mubarak told the Egyptian people on Thursday that he would delegate authority to Vice President Omar Suleiman but that he would not resign, enraging hundreds of thousands gathered to hail his departure and setting in motion a volatile new stage in the three-week uprising.
articles.byline: By Anthony Shadid and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Search for Low Airfares Gets More Competitive
articles.snippet: Google is looking to enter air travel search, and American Airlines wants to bypass online agents like Expedia.
articles.abstract: Google is looking to enter air travel search, and American Airlines wants to bypass online agents like Expedia.
articles.lead_paragraph: The familiar world of online air travel search is about to get a major shake-up.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Afghan Proposal Would Clamp Down on Women’s Shelters
articles.snippet: The rules, which would require women at shelters to appear before a government panel, point to the suspicion that shelters generate in Afghan society.
articles.abstract: The rules, which would require women at shelters to appear before a government panel, point to the suspicion that shelters generate in Afghan society.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  After her parents threw her out of the house for refusing to marry a 52-year-old widower with five children, Sabra, 18, boarded a bus that dropped her, afraid and confused, in downtown Kabul. She slept in a mosque for days, barely eating, until a woman took pity on her and put her in touch with human rights workers, who escorted her to a women’s shelter.
